title: Best Practices in donor reporting and compliance for first time grant recipients
text: As an organisation or entity, the thought of first time funding from a donor can be both exciting and a little scary at the same time. However, the thought of how to effectively manage that grant, the people and systems you have in place could raise a few questions or concerns. One might wonder, how best can we deliver on this grant? How can we deliver quality outputs as per the agreement, whilst ensuring the donor is happy with accountability and regularly updated on progress? All these questions and concerns can be addressed by putting in place a few key processes, practices and systems.

title: Best Practices in donor reporting and compliance for first time grant recipients
text:
Project Inception/Kick-off meeting
Once an organisation acquires new funding, it is imperative to organise an inception or kick-off meeting. This meeting should bring together staff from all the relevant departments, with the aim of familiarising with the grant agreement, discussing the expectations, dos and don’t with regards to the project. During this meeting, functions like programme, M&E, HR and finance are able to know what role they play for project success to be achieved. The compliance and reporting requirements should be adequately discussed to ensure understanding by all the different departments.

title: Best Practices in donor reporting and compliance for first time grant recipients
Best Practices in donor reporting and compliance for first time grant recipients
text:
Pre-Award
In the pre-award phase, an organisation should already be researching on or even asking the donor what their reporting requirements are like, and what expectations that particular donor has in terms of reporting and compliance. There are different kinds of donors ranging from multilateral, and bilateral institutions, private foundations and corporations, and each of these have very unique reporting and compliance requirements.

title: Best Practices in donor reporting and compliance for first time grant recipients
text:
Project Team (HR) Mobilisation
The first thing for any organisation to have in place is the right people to deliver on the project supported by the grant funding. There should be clearly defined roles and responsibilities, including the reporting lines to ensure that every member of the team is aware of the role they play in project success.

title: Best Practices in donor reporting and compliance for first time grant recipients
text:
Reporting
It is important to develop a reporting schedule and share the reporting templates, both technical and financial with the programme, M&E and finance team members, so they can get an appreciation of them beforehand. In many cases, the templates are shared by the donor and they have clear guidance and description on what information is expected in certain sections, for instance key activities during the reporting period, achievements, challenges and lessons learnt. It is also important to take note of issues like word and character limits so as to keep the information within the donor’s requirements.

title: Best Practices in donor reporting and compliance for first time grant recipients
text:
Communication
The organisation should have a clear line of communication with the donor. A focal point must be designated to make all relevant communication pertaining to the project and reporting with the donor. Regular communication and updates with the donor builds positive relationships and makes it easier to resolve any challenges you encounter in a timely manner. It is good for the donor to be kept abreast of key developments even before submission of reports.

title: Best Practices in donor reporting and compliance for first time grant recipients
text:
Documentation
The keeping or storage of grant related materials and documents is a good practice that goes a long way to ease reporting and compliance. The important documentation pertaining to a project should be easily accessible by the project team members. An organisation can think of either having a centralised location or drive that can be used to store all relevant information pertaining to the project, right from grant agreements, reports, and communication or visibility materials.
The documentation of key activities as and when they happen, so that once a report is required, there is already something in draft state. This also makes it easier to recall events when they have just taken place and everything is fresh as opposed to waiting to burn the midnight oil many months down the road with pressing deadlines.

title: The Road to Better Healthcare Financing in Uganda: Challenges and Opportunities
text: As Uganda strives to achieve the Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) No. 3 i.e., to improve the health and wellbeing of the population, a crucial aspect to address is healthcare financing. While some progress has been made over the past decade, the healthcare system continues to face significant challenges e.g. limited access to quality and affordable care for millions of Ugandans. However, there are also opportunities to transform healthcare financing in Uganda into a more sustainable and equitable system. This article explores both the challenges to address and opportunities to be seized to ensure better healthcare for the people of Uganda.

title: The Road to Better Healthcare Financing in Uganda: Challenges and Opportunities
text:
Challenges
From 2009 to 2019, Uganda’s health expenditure per capita decreased from $44 to $32, a negative trend when compared to other East African neighbors. For instance, Kenya’s expenditure grew from $55 to $83 during the same period, while Rwanda’s increased from $45 to $51. This declining trend in Uganda’s health spending per capita, highlights the pressing need for further investment in the healthcare sector.
A second major challenge facing Uganda is the high dependency on out-of-pocket payments for healthcare services. According to the World Health Organization, out-of-pocket payments accounted for 41% of Uganda’s total health expenditure in 2017, a proportion which hasn’t changed much in the last 5 years. This financial burden often leads to impoverishment and limits access to essential health services, particularly for the poorest and most vulnerable populations.
Take, for instance, the story of Jane, a mother of three living in a rural village in Pakwach. When her youngest child fell ill with malaria, she had to travel over 20 miles to reach the nearest health center. The cost of treatment drained her family’s meager savings, forcing them to borrow money from relatives and neighbors to afford the life-saving care her child needed.
Another challenge is the inequitable distribution of healthcare resources across the country. Rural areas, which house a majority of Uganda’s population, often have limited access to well-equipped health facilities and skilled healthcare professionals. This disparity further exacerbates the health inequalities experienced by Ugandans.
Consider also the story of Paul, a small-scale farmer in rural Kabale, who struggles to manage his diabetes. The nearest health facility with the capacity to monitor and treat his condition is a two-hour bus ride away. The cost of transportation, combined with the high out-of-pocket expenses for medications and tests, has left him with an impossible choice: risk his health by skipping treatments or plunge his family into debt.

title: The Road to Better Healthcare Financing in Uganda: Challenges and Opportunities
text:
Opportunities
Despite these challenges, there are opportunities to strengthen Uganda’s healthcare financing system. Implementing policies that increase public funding for healthcare is a crucial step in reducing out-of-pocket expenses and expanding access to essential services. For instance, the government could prioritize increasing its budgetary allocation to the health sector, which currently falls short of the 15% target set by the African Union’s Abuja Declaration.
Expanding health insurance coverage is another potential avenue to improve healthcare financing. By establishing a national health insurance scheme that covers a wide range of services, the government can pool resources to provide affordable, quality care to all Ugandans. This approach has been successful in countries like Rwanda, where community-based health insurance schemes have led to increased healthcare utilization and financial risk protection.
Furthermore, the government can leverage public-private partnerships (PPPs) to address gaps in healthcare infrastructure and service delivery. By engaging private sector expertise and resources, the government can stimulate investments in healthcare facilities, particularly in rural areas where access is limited. PPPs can also foster innovations in healthcare delivery, such as telemedicine, which can help bridge the gap between urban and rural populations.
Last but not least, the government also has the opportunity to invest in primary healthcare, focusing on preventive and promotive interventions. Strengthening primary care can yield long-term benefits, reducing the burden on the healthcare system, improving health outcomes, and saving lives. By prioritizing primary care, the government can ensure that Ugandans receive the essential services they need to lead healthy lives.

title: The Road to Better Healthcare Financing in Uganda: Challenges and Opportunities
text:
Call to action:
To wrap up, while Uganda faces significant challenges in healthcare financing, there are also numerous opportunities for improvement. By embracing a combination of increased public funding, expanded health insurance coverage, public-private partnerships, and investment in primary healthcare, the government can build a more equitable and sustainable healthcare system for all citizens. The time to act is now, as the health and wellbeing of our people hang in the balance.
